Introduction

Bullous pemphigoid (BP) and pemphigus vulgaris (PV) are autoimmune diseases characterized by decreased epidermal integrity.  BP causes subepidermal blistering and tends to affect older adults, whereas PV involves intraepidermal blistering and affects a younger population.

Bullous pemphigoid

Pathophysiology

BP is caused by autoantibodies targeting the basement membrane zone of the epidermis, specifically BP180 (collagen XVII) and BP230, which are components of hemidesmosomes (

figure 1
).  This autoimmune reaction triggers a cascade of inflammation, leading to separation of the epidermis from the dermis.  Because the overlying epidermis is relatively intact, BP results in tense subepidermal blisters.

Risk factors

  • Age:  Age >60
  • Medications:  Furosemide, penicillamine, and certain antibiotics (eg, sulfonamides)
  • Neurological conditions:  Parkinson disease, multiple sclerosis
  • Genetic predisposition:  HLA-DQB1 has been associated with increased susceptibility

Clinical presentation

  • Skin lesions:  May initially cause papules or urticarial plaques, which progress over weeks to form tense, large bullae on an erythematous or normal-appearing base (
    image 1
    ).  Ruptured bullae may appear as shallow erosions.
  • Pruritus:  Itching is common and often precedes blister formation.
  • Mucosal involvement:  Rare in BP but may occur in severe cases.


Diagnosis



The diagnosis of BP is based on clinical findings and confirmed through histopathologic and serologic studies:

  • Skin biopsy:  Shows subepidermal blistering with an inflammatory infiltrate composed mainly of eosinophils (
    image 2
    ).
  • DIF:  reveals linear deposition of IgG and C3 along the basement membrane at the dermoepidermal junction (
    image 3
    ); this is diagnostic of BP.
  • Laboratory serologic studies:  Circulating anti-BP180 and BP230 antibodies, detected via enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA).


Management

  • First-line therapy:  High-potency topical corticosteroids (eg, clobetasol).  Systemic corticosteroids are used in widespread disease (eg, >20% of body surface area).
  • Corticosteroid-sparing agents:  Doxycycline, dapsone, azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, or methotrexate can be considered to reduce corticosteroid exposure.
  • Biologics:  Rituximab or omalizumab are considered in refractory cases.
  • Adjunct therapies:  Antihistamines for pruritus and wound care for blistered areas.


Complications

  • Infection:  Secondary bacterial infections of skin lesions.
  • Corticosteroid side effects:  Long-term use can lead to osteoporosis, hyperglycemia, and immunosuppression.
  • Scarring:  Although less common than in other blistering diseases, scarring can occur in chronic cases.


Prognosis

The disease may last months to years, but many patients achieve remission.  Relapses are common, especially during tapering of therapy.  Disease-specific mortality is modest and primarily related to infection, but overall mortality (including comorbid conditions) is significantly higher.

Pemphigus vulgaris

Pathophysiology

PV is an autoimmune disease caused by antibodies against desmoglein-1 and desmoglein-3, components of desmosomes that are necessary for keratinocyte adhesion in the epidermis (

figure 2
).  The loss of cell-to-cell adhesion (acantholysis) results in loose, fragile intraepidermal blistering and erosions.

Risk factors

  • Age:  Most common at age 40-60
  • Ethnicity:  Ashkenazi Jewish, Mediterranean, and South Asian populations
  • Medications:  Rarely, drugs such as penicillamine and ACE inhibitors can trigger PV
  • Genetic predisposition:  HLA-DR4 and HLA-DQ3 associated with increased risk


Clinical presentation

  • Skin lesions:  Flaccid, easily ruptured blisters on normal or erythematous skin.  Lesions often coalesce, leading to painful erosions.
  • Mucosal involvement:  Almost universal, with painful erosions in the oral mucosa, pharynx, or genitals.  Oral lesions may precede skin involvement.  The presence of mucosal lesions strongly favors the diagnosis of PV over BP.
  • Nikolsky sign:  Gentle pressure or friction to the skin (either at the margin of a blister or in normal-appearing skin) induces blister formation; the sign suggests the diagnosis of PV but is not highly sensitive or specific.


Diagnosis

Diagnosis is confirmed with histopathology and serologic testing:

  • Skin biopsy:  demonstrates acantholysis, or loss of keratinocyte adhesion, within the epidermis, leading to the formation of suprabasal blisters (
    image 4
    ).  The basal keratinocytes remain adherent to the basement membrane, often described as a "row of tombstones."
  • DIF:  IgG and C3 deposition in a characteristic fishnet pattern within the epidermis; this distinguishes PV from BP
  • Laboratory serologic testing:  Detection of circulating antibodies against desmoglein-1 and desmoglein-3 by ELISA.


Management

  • First-line therapy:  Systemic corticosteroids (eg, prednisone) to control disease activity.
  • Immunosuppressants:  Corticosteroid-sparing agents such as azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, or rituximab are often required for long-term management and may be started concurrently with prednisone.
  • Topical therapies:  Topical corticosteroids may be useful for localized skin or mucosal involvement, but systemic treatment is usually necessary.


Complications

  • Infections:  Open erosions are prone to secondary bacterial infections and sepsis.
  • Electrolyte imbalances:  Due to fluid loss from extensive skin involvement.
  • Malnutrition:  Painful oral erosions can impair food intake, leading to weight loss.
  • Corticosteroid side effects:  Similar to BP, long-term steroid use can cause osteoporosis, diabetes, and immunosuppression.


Prognosis

Untreated PV has high mortality, often due to sepsis from infection of skin lesions or respiratory failure from mucosal involvement.  With appropriate treatment, most patients achieve remission, although relapses are common and long-term therapy is often required.  In addition to disease-specific treatment, extensive wound care and additional supportive measures may be needed to minimize morbidity.

Differential diagnosis

Distinction between BP and PV is definitively established with histopathology and immunofluorescence staining, supported by serologic studies (

).  However, certain clinical features can be suggestive for a preliminary diagnosis:

  • Patients with BP are typically older (age >60) relative to PV (mostly age <60).
  • Mucosal lesions are usually present in PV but uncommon in BP.
  • The bullous lesions in PV are soft and fragile with easy desquamation, whereas tense bullae are more typical in BP.

Other blistering conditions that should be considered in the differential diagnosis include the following:

  • Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS):  Widespread mucocutaneous necrosis and desquamation (
    image 5
    ), usually drug-induced, and associated with systemic symptoms.
  • Erythema multiforme:  Target lesions (
    image 6
    ) that may form microvesicles or blisters.  Mucosal lesions are common.  Often triggered by infections or drugs.  Typically self-limiting.
  • Paraneoplastic pemphigus:  Similar clinical features but often associated with underlying malignancy, particularly non-Hodgkin lymphoma or chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis:  severely pruritic papulovesicular lesions (
    image 7
    ), predominantly at the elbows, knees, and gluteal cleft; associated with gluten sensitivity, granular IgA deposits at the dermoepidermal junction.
  • Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita:  Causes tense bullae resembling BP but is more common on the extremities and other trauma-prone areas and is often associated with mucosal lesions.
  • Drug-induced bullous eruptions:  May mimic BP but typically have a more abrupt onset and a clear temporal relationship to drug exposure.


Summary

Bullous pemphigoid (BP) and pemphigus vulgaris (PV) are autoimmune blistering diseases that, while sharing some clinical features, have distinct pathophysiological mechanisms and differences in management.  BP typically presents with tense subepidermal blisters, often in older adults, and is managed primarily with topical and systemic corticosteroids.  In contrast, PV is characterized by flaccid intraepidermal blisters, significant mucosal involvement, and a higher risk of serious complications if not adequately treated with systemic corticosteroids and immunosuppressive therapy.  Early diagnosis and appropriate intervention are key in both conditions to prevent complications and improve outcomes.
